docs.lead_paragraph: Vonage, an Internet Phone Provider, Files for an Initial Public Offering Vonage Holdings, a provider of Internet-based telephone service, filed for an initial public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to $250 million in stock. The move to go public is the first for an Internet phone provider and a sign of a new level of prominence for a technology that has become a serious threat to traditional phone companies. [Page C1.] Experts Point to a Distortion Behind Trade Figures Analysts say an evolving global supply chain -- which usually tags goods at their final assembly stop -- is distorting global trade figures, which serve to inflate China into a bigger trade threat than it may actually be. That kind of distortion is likely to appear again on Friday, when the Commerce Department announces the American trade deficit with China. [C1.] A Makeover and a Reunion for Barbie and Ken Like a publicist trying to revive the moribund career of a Hollywood star, Barbie's manufacturer, Mattel, is pulling out all the stops to put her back on her feet after her sales have flagged. For one thing, after a heart-wrenching, two-year separation Ken and Barbie are headed for a romantic reunion, according to their handlers. Barbie's fate holds wide-ranging implications not just for Mattel, where the doll accounts for 20 percent of sales, but the entire toy industry. [C1.] G.M. Joins Trend of Pulling Back Retiree Benefits G.M. is like many other once impregnable American corporate titans in arguing that reducing the burden of caring for retirees has become essential to compete against foreign companies with lower benefit costs and domestic rivals with younger work forces and less generous benefit packages. [C1.] Regulator Fines an Analyst and His Firm A prominent Wall Street analyst has been fined $220,000, and his firm, Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, has been fined $350,000, accused of violating NASD rules that were put into place after a scandal that highlighted analysts who publicly promoted stocks they privately derided. [C5.] I.B.M. Announces Products That Use Game Technology I.B.M. is betting on video game technology to bring supercomputer-caliber visualization tools to its mainstream corporate market and to reduce the computing costs of daunting tasks like hunting for oil, discovering new drugs and exploring the human body. [C4.] Nortel Offers to Settle Suits for $2.4 Billion Nortel Networks, the troubled maker of telecommunications equipment, offered about $2.4 billion in cash and stock to settle two class-action lawsuits over an accounting debacle two years ago. [C7.] Testimony on Shifting of Losses at Enron Fraud Trial At the fraud trial of two former Enron executives, the former head of investor relations testified that the shifting of hundreds of millions of dollars in losses from one company unit to another may not have been entirely secret outside the company. [C11.] Major Stock Indicators Post Increases Stocks gained after a sales forecast from Cisco Systems suggested that the profit outlook for technology companies might be improving. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 108.86 points, to 10,858.62. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 10.87 points, to 1265.65. 6. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 22.02 points, to 2,266.98. [C11.] For Olympics, Advertisers Broaden Their Range Just as the sponsors of Super Bowl XL extended their glitzy, expensive commercials beyond the game -- onto Web sites, cellphones, cinema screens and video iPods -- so too will the scores of marketers that plan to run spots during the NBC Universal television coverage of the Olympic Winter Games, to be held in Turin, Italy, from tomorrow through Feb. 26. The expansion of the Olympic campaigns into other media is emblematic of the efforts advertisers are making to reach consumers who are increasingly able to zap, zip through and otherwise avoid traditional TV pitches. Stuart Elliott: Advertising [C6.] Risk to Baby Found When Mother Takes Antidepressant Expectant mothers who took antidepressants like Prozac late in their pregnancy were significantly more likely to give birth to an infant with a rare but serious breathing problem, doctors are reporting. [A19.] Twenty-five people died suddenly and another 54 suffered serious unexplained heart problems while taking stimulant drugs like Ritalin from 1999 through 2003, according to reports sent to drug regulators. [A19.] Gulf Between Large and Small Firms on Asbestos Bill Several large companies are backing legislation that would create a $140 billion fund for victims of asbestos, arguing they want to put their asbestos litigation and liabilities behind them. But some smaller businesses say the bill will drive them into Chapter 11 bankruptcy. [C3.] Protecting and Repairing Tiny Music Players The very portability of an MP3 player can be its undoing -- too often, the pocket-size gadgets are dropped, scratched, drowned or exposed to extreme temperatures. But there are ways to prevent damage in the first place or to have the players repaired, for a price. Circuits. [C9.]
docs.snippet: Vonage, an Internet Phone Provider, Files for an Initial Public Offering  Vonage Holdings, a provider of Internet-based telephone service, filed for an initial public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to $250 million in...

docs.lead_paragraph: A Family Daughter By Maile Meloy 325 pages. Scribner. $24. Maile Meloy's two novels are joined at the hip in a strange way. Both describe the same intensely complicated California family, the Santerres. Some aspects of the Santerre history turn up in both books.

headline.main: A Second Novel Casts the First in a Whole New Light

docs.snippet: Maile Meloy's first novel appears in her second novel as a book written by one of her characters.

docs.lead_paragraph: Japanese officials said Tuesday that Princess Kiko, the wife of Emperor Akihito's second son, Prince Akishino, is pregnant, raising hopes for a long-awaited male heir to one of the world's oldest hereditary monarchies and throwing into doubt imperial law revisions that would allow a female line to hold the throne. The Imperial Household Agency said an ultrasound test had shown Princess Kiko to be about six weeks pregnant, though it was too early to know the child's sex. Kiko, 39, already has two daughters, Kako, 11, and Mako, 14. Crown Princess Masako, 42, the wife of Crown Prince Naruhito, also has a daughter, 4-year-old Princess Aiko.

headline.main: Japanese Princess Expects, And Many Hope (for a Boy)

docs.abstract: Princess Kiko, wife of Japanese Emporer Akihito's second son, Prince Akishino, is pregnant; Kiko already has two daughters; Crown Princess Masako, wife of Crown Prince Naruhito, also has daughter, Princess Aiko; announcement of Kiko's pregancy prompts many lawmakers who oppose female heir to call halt to debate on revising law, until unborn baby's sex is known; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Imperial Household Agency said an ultrasound showed Princess Kiko to be about six weeks pregnant, though it was too early to know the child's sex.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Big Why By Michael Winter 375 pages. Bloomsbury. $24.95. In his new novel, Michael Winter is forthcoming about what he has lifted from where. His book about a year in the life of the artist Rockwell Kent is told in the first person, as if the writer were Kent himself, and the story, Mr. Winter relates, was inspired by some of the artist's own writings. Mr. Winter has also ''plundered many books on Newfoundland to supply color and detail,'' as well as a documentary film, two art catalogs and an unpublished thesis. Of course, as a novelist -- even a ''historical'' one -- he's under no obligation to reveal his sources, and so in this age of literary lying, he comes off as refreshingly candid.

headline.main: Calamitous Year in the Life Of a Philandering Artist

docs.snippet: Michael Winter's novel about a year in the life of the artist Rockwell Kent is told in the first person, and was inspired by the artist's own writings.
